PROJECT: Customer Portal Redesign
MEETING: Team Kickoff
DATE: January 15, 2025
ATTENDEES: Sarah (PM), Alex (UX), Jordan (Dev Lead), Casey (QA), Morgan (BA), Taylor (Designer)

NOTES:
- Sarah welcomed everyone and thanked them for joining the project
- Went through project charter and objectives
- Q: Alex asked 'What's our timeline for this project?'
- A: Sarah explained 6-month timeline with quarterly milestones
- Q: Jordan asked 'Who has final say on technical architecture decisions?'
- A: Sarah said 'We'll discuss that' but didn't provide clear answer
- Q: Casey asked 'How often do we meet as a team?'
- A: Sarah suggested 'Let's figure that out as we go'
- Q: Morgan asked 'Do I report to you or my functional manager?'
- A: Sarah said 'Good question - I'll get back to you on that'
- Q: Taylor raised hand and quietly asked 'Sorry, what exactly is my role on this project?'
- Everyone nodded politely during Sarah's overview
- No one challenged any information presented
- Several people took detailed notes
- Meeting ended 10 minutes early
- Alex and Jordan stayed after to ask Sarah similar questions privately

ACTION ITEMS:
- Sarah to create meeting schedule (TBD)
- Sarah to clarify reporting relationships (TBD)
- Sarah to define roles more clearly (TBD)

questions.question: What team development stage is this team in?
questions.explanation: First meeting (kickoff), polite behavior ('nodded politely'), many questions about basic structure (timeline, meetings, roles, reporting), no one challenged information, uncertain about roles ('what exactly is my role?'), people staying after to ask questions privately (hesitant to speak up), need for clarity and structure evident.

questions.question: What leadership issues do you see?
questions.correct: Lack of structure and clarity, missed opportunity to establish foundation, inappropriate leadership style (too hands-off for Forming), multiple people asking same questions separately
questions.explanation: Sarah didn't provide clear answers to fundamental questions. 'We'll figure that out as we go' = abdicating responsibility. Forming teams need directive leadership. Sarah being too hands-off, not providing the structure team clearly needs, expecting team to self-organize prematurely.

questions.question: What should Sarah do immediately after this meeting?
questions.correct: Create and share RACI matrix, establish meeting schedule, clarify reporting relationships, define decision-making process, create ground rules, schedule individual check-ins
questions.explanation: Within 24 hours: Create RACI matrix to define roles explicitly, establish regular team meetings, clarify reporting relationships, define decision-making process, create ground rules with team, schedule individual check-ins. Leadership Style Needed: Authoritative - Provide clear vision and structure, be decisive and directive.

key_insights: Forming teams need structure immediately - can't wait to 'figure it out as we go'
Polite behavior and many questions = classic Forming indicators
PM must provide direction in Forming stage, not delegate prematurely
Multiple people asking same questions separately = need for team-wide clarity

leadership_style_matcher.title: Leadership Style Matcher
leadership_style_matcher.description: Match situations to appropriate leadership styles

scenarios.scenario: New team, first meeting. Team members are polite but asking many questions about roles and processes.
scenarios.explanation: Forming stage requires structure and direction. PM must provide clear vision, establish processes, and make decisions. Team cannot self-organize yet.

whyNotOthers.Democratic: Team doesn't have foundation to participate in decisions yet
whyNotOthers.Delegating: Too early - team needs structure first
whyNotOthers.Affiliative: Relationships important but structure is priority in Forming

scenarios.scenario: Team arguing about technical approach. Power struggles evident. Two senior members competing for influence.
scenarios.explanation: Storming stage requires facilitation. PM should coach team through conflict, help them work through disagreements, stay neutral, and teach conflict resolution.

whyNotOthers.Commanding: Forcing decision drives conflict underground, doesn't help team learn
whyNotOthers.Avoiding: Conflict needs to be addressed, not ignored
whyNotOthers.Democratic: Team is in conflict - need to resolve that first before making decisions together

scenarios.scenario: High-performing team that self-organizes effectively. New complex challenge arises. Team is concerned but engaged.
scenarios.explanation: Performing stage team has earned trust. PM should maintain autonomy, offer support when requested, trust team's capability, and focus on removing obstacles.

whyNotOthers.Commanding: Would regress team to Forming, shows lack of trust
whyNotOthers.Pacesetting: Team doesn't need PM to set pace - they're already performing
whyNotOthers.Coaching: Team is already capable - don't need development, need empowerment

scenarios.scenario: Team just completed brutal 3-month crunch. Exhausted, irritable, relationships strained. Morale very low.
scenarios.explanation: Team crisis requires people-first approach. PM should acknowledge sacrifice, provide recovery time, repair relationships, show genuine care, and prioritize well-being over tasks.

whyNotOthers.Pacesetting: Would worsen burnout, team needs recovery not more pressure
whyNotOthers.Commanding: Would damage relationships further, ignores emotional needs
whyNotOthers.Democratic: Team needs emotional support first, not decision-making involvement

scenarios.scenario: Production system crashed. Customers affected. Team waiting for direction. Need immediate action.
scenarios.explanation: Crisis situation requires immediate response. PM must provide clear orders, make decisions quickly, coordinate response, and ensure safety. Transition to other styles after crisis.

whyNotOthers.Democratic: No time for discussion in crisis
whyNotOthers.Affiliative: Relationships important but action is priority in emergency

scenarios.scenario: Team lacks clarity on project direction. Multiple competing priorities. Need alignment and motivation.
scenarios.explanation: Team needs vision and direction. PM should provide clear vision, explain the 'why', align team around goals, inspire confidence, and allow autonomy in execution.

whyNotOthers.Commanding: Too directive - team needs vision not just orders
whyNotOthers.Democratic: Team lacks clarity to participate effectively yet
whyNotOthers.Pacesetting: Team needs direction first, not pace-setting

Jamie is trying to contribute but feels excluded

validPoints.existingTeam: They've invested in their process and it works. Change is disruptive.

pm.realIssue: Integration challenge - need to help Jamie fit in while also being open to improvements. Team may temporarily regress from Performing to Norming.
pm.solution: 1. Acknowledge both perspectives. 2. Create structured integration (not just 'figure it out'). 3. Facilitate discussion about process improvements (don't dismiss Jamie's ideas, don't force changes). 4. Help team see Jamie's value. 5. Be patient - integration takes time.

insight.title: Adding members to performing teams requires intentional integration
insight.revelation: Performing teams can regress when new members join. The real issue isn't the new person or the existing team - it's the lack of intentional integration process. Both sides need support: existing team needs reassurance their process is valued, new member needs pathway to contribute.
insight.bestApproach: Don't assume high-performing teams will automatically integrate new members. Create structured onboarding, facilitate discussions about improvements (not just accept or reject), acknowledge both perspectives, and be patient with temporary regression.
insight.eiConnection: Social awareness: Recognizing both the existing team's protective feelings and the new member's exclusion. Relationship management: Facilitating integration without taking sides.
insight.examTip: PMP exam scenarios often test whether you'll force integration or facilitate it. The answer is usually to facilitate discussion and create structure, not to pick a side.

deep_dive.introduction: Supporting team performance is one of the most nuanced competencies for project managers. Unlike functional managers who have formal authority over team members' careers, project managers must influence performance through feedback, coaching, recognition, and creating environments where people can excel. This deep dive explores the frameworks, techniques, and best practices that enable project managers to maximize team performance.

options.text: Reassign her work to other team members to protect the project schedule

options.text: Schedule a private 1-on-1 to express concern and understand what's happening
options.outcome: SUCCESS: The sudden change from strong to declining performance signals something changed. Before taking any action, you need to understand the root cause. options.text: Notify her functional manager about the performance decline

options.text: That's really your functional manager's job. You should ask them.

PM creates development plan with Alex focused on technical leadership path. Includes leading code reviews, mentoring junior devs, and architecture involvement.
Alex asks to lead the security module redesign‚Äîthe most complex component. PM hesitates but agrees with extra check-ins.

Alex delivers security module on time with zero critical bugs. QA praises the thoroughness. PM recognizes Alex publicly in sprint review.

phase_1.pattern: Alex performed well but received no attention. PM focused on 'fires' and neglected solid contributors.
pm_mistakes: Didn't intervene when Alex's idea was dismissed

phase_1.lesson: Solid performers need attention too. Absence of problems ‚â† presence of engagement.

feedback_type_matcher.title: Feedback Type Matcher
feedback_type_matcher.description: Match Situations to Appropriate Feedback Approaches

scenarios.situation: Developer's code caused a production incident. They've already fixed it. This is the first time.

best_match.timing: Same day, after resolution (timely but not in crisis)

scenarios.sbi_example: After the release yesterday, your code change caused a 2-hour outage affecting 500 customers. I know you fixed it quickly. Let's discuss what we can do differently in testing to prevent this.

scenarios.situation: Team member went above and beyond to help a colleague meet a deadline by staying late.

best_match.delivery: Private first, ask about public (respect preference)

scenarios.sbi_example: Yesterday when Jordan was struggling to meet the deadline, you stayed late to help them finish. That collaboration allowed us to deliver on time and showed real team spirit. Would you be comfortable if I shared this in the sprint review?

team_member_perspectives.title: Team Member Perspectives
team_member_perspectives.description: Experience Feedback from the Receiving End

scenarios.title: The Bug in Production
scenarios.context: You're a developer. Your code caused a production bug that affected customers for 2 hours. You've already fixed it. Your PM asks to speak with you.

version_a.pm_says: Your code broke production again. This is exactly the kind of carelessness I was worried about. We can't keep having these issues. I need you to be more careful. This affects the whole team's reputation. I'm documenting this conversation.

analysis.approach: Blaming, Judgmental, Past-focused, Threatening, PM as judge
analysis.impact: Defensive, resentful, may hide future issues, updates resume

version_b.pm_says: I saw the production issue earlier‚ÄîI know you already fixed it, thank you for the quick response. I wanted to check in: what happened from your perspective? [listens] What do you think we could do differently in our process to catch this earlier? [listens] I appreciate you owning the fix quickly. Let's implement those process improvements you mentioned.

analysis.approach: Factual, Curious, Future-focused, Collaborative, PM as partner
analysis.impact: Accountable, engaged, suggests improvements, feels supported

scenarios.title: The Invisible Contribution
scenarios.context: You're a developer who spends significant time reviewing others' code, catching bugs, and helping junior team members. Your deliverables are average because of this work. Performance review time approaches.

version_a.pm_says: Looking at your velocity, you're below the team average. I need you to focus more on your own deliverables. The team needs everyone contributing at full capacity.

analysis.approach: Sees only metrics, Single measure, Criticism, Demands change, Makes you feel invisible
analysis.impact: Stop helping others, feel punished for team contribution, disengage

version_b.pm_says: I've been looking at team data, and I noticed something. Your individual velocity is below average, but I also see that you've done 40% of all code reviews and junior team members consistently request your help. That mentoring work doesn't show up in sprint points, but it's hugely valuable. How can we make sure you're recognized for both your delivery AND your team contributions? Should we adjust how we capture this work?

analysis.approach: Sees full contribution, Multiple measures, Recognition + curiosity, Asks for input, Makes you feel seen
analysis.impact: Continue team contribution, feel valued, engage more deeply

key_lessons: Be Seen - Notice my contributions‚Äîespecially the invisible ones
Be Heard - Ask my perspective before judging my performance
Be Respected - Match recognition to my preferences, not yours
Be Developed - Invest in my growth, not just my output
Be Supported - When I struggle, assume context before assuming fault
